#5. R Nuts and Bolts

#5.1 Entering Input

```{r}
x <- 1
print(x)
x
msg <- "hello"
```
 
#5.2 Evaluation
```{r}
x <- 5 ## nothing printed
x ## auto-printing occurs
print(x) ## explicit printing

x <- 11:30
x
```
#5.6 Creating Vectors

```{r}
x <- c(0.5, 0.6) ## numeric
x <- c(TRUE, FALSE) ## logical
x <- c(T, F) ## logical
x <- c("a", "b", "c") ## character
x <- 9:29 ## integer
x <- c(1+0i, 2+4i) ## complex
x <- vector("numeric", length = 10)
x
```

#5.7 Mixing Objects
```{r}
y <- c(1.7, "a") ## character
y <- c(TRUE, 2) ## numeric
y <- c("a", TRUE) ## character
```

#5.8 Explicit Coercion
```{r}
x <- 0:6
class(x)
as.numeric(x)

as.logical(x)

as.character(x)

```


Sometimes, R can't figure out how to coerce an object and this can result in NAs being produced.

```{r}
x <- c("a", "b", "c")
as.numeric(x)
as.logical(x)
as.complex(x)

```
#5.9 Matrices

```{r}
m <- matrix(nrow = 2, ncol = 3)
m
dim(m)
attributes(m)
```
```{r}
m <- matrix(1:6, nrow = 2, ncol = 3)
m
```
m <- matrix(1:6, nrow = 2, ncol = 3)
```{r}
m <- 1:10
m
dim(m) <- c(2, 5)
m

```

Matrices can be created by column-binding or row-binding with the cbind() and rbind() functions.

```{r}
x <- 1:3
y <- 10:12
cbind(x, y)

```




```{r}
rbind(x, y)

```
#5.10 Lists
```{r}
x <- list(1, "a", TRUE, 1 + 4i)
x
```

We can also create an empty list of a prespecified length with the vector() function
```{r}
x <- vector("list", length = 5)
x
```


#5.11 Factors
```{r}
x <- factor(c("yes", "yes", "no", "yes", "no"))
x
```

```{r}
table(x)
```

```{r}
 ## See the underlying representation of factor
unclass(x)

```
#5.12 Missing Values
```{r}
## Create a vector with NAs in it
x <- c(1, 2, NA, 10, 3)
## Return a logical vector indicating which elements are NA
is.na(x)

```


```{r}
## Return a logical vector indicating which elements are NaN
is.nan(x)
```

```{r}
## Now create a vector with both NA and NaN values
x <- c(1, 2, NaN, NA, 4)
is.na(x)
```

```{r}
is.nan(x)

```


#5.13 Data Frames
```{r}
x <- data.frame(foo = 1:4, bar = c(T, T, F, F))
x
```




```{r}
nrow(x)

```

```{r}
ncol(x)

```


#5.14 Names
```{r}
x <- 1:3
names(x)

```

```{r}
names(x) <- c("New York", "Seattle", "Los Angeles")
x
```
```{r}
names(x)

```

Lists can also have names, which is often very useful.
```{r}
x <- list("Los Angeles" = 1, Boston = 2, London = 3)
x
```



```{r}
names(x)
```

Matrices can have both column and row names.




```{r}
m <- matrix(1:4, nrow = 2, ncol = 2)
dimnames(m) <- list(c("a", "b"), c("c", "d"))
m

```

Column names and row names can be set separately using the colnames() and rownames()functions.

```{r}
colnames(m) <- c("h", "f")
rownames(m) <- c("x", "z")
m

```
